user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketAddrFromString_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_SocketAddrFromString_Impl(OS_SockAddr_t *Addr, const char *string)
{
    void *                  addrbuffer;
    OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *Accessor;

    Accessor = (OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *)&Addr->AddrData;

    switch (Accessor->sa.sa_family)
    {
        case AF_INET:
            addrbuffer = &Accessor->sa_in.sin_addr;
            break;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
        case AF_INET6:
            addrbuffer = &Accessor->sa_in6.sin6_addr;
            break;
#endif
        default:
            return OS_ERR_BAD_ADDRESS;
            break;
    }

    /* This function is defined as returning 1 on success, not 0 */
    if (inet_pton(Accessor->sa.sa_family, string, addrbuffer) != 1)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SocketAddrFromString_Impl:
typedef struct
{
    size_t            ActualLength; /**< @brief Length of the actual address data */
    OS_SockAddrData_t AddrData;     /**< @brief Abstract Address data */
} OS_SockAddr_t
...
typedef union
{
    char               data[OS_SOCKADDR_MAX_LEN];
    struct sockaddr    sa;
    struct sockaddr_in sa_in;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
    struct sockaddr_in6 sa_in6;
#endif
} OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No compiler-specific language extensions are used in the provided code. I checked for common extension markers such as identifiers beginning with double underscores or named compiler extensions (e.g. __attribute__, __asm, __builtin_*, __typeof__, __extension__, pragmas that are implementation-specific), and none are present. The use of: - preprocessor conditional #ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6 (standard preprocessor feature), - casts (e.g. (OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *)&Addr->AddrData), - unions and struct members, - standard macros/constants (AF_INET / AF_INET6), and - the POSIX function inet_pton, are all standard C or standard library/OS APIs rather than compiler language extensions. The extra 'break' after the 'return' is dead code but is not a language extension. Therefore there are no fragments that need further investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 (use of language extensions).
